title: R44369
content: Senate committees are required to adopt rules that are not inconsistent with Senate Rule XXVI. This requirement dates back to the 1970 Legislative Reorganization Act, which built on the 1946 Legislative Reorganization Act. Committees must have their rules printed in the Congressional Record by March 1 of the first year of a Congress. The Senate also publishes a compilation of all committee rules each Congress. Committee rules govern actions in committee proceedings and are enforced by members. Senate cannot enforce committee rules on the floor later. Committees may have traditions affecting procedures. Committee rules govern actions in committee proceedings and are enforced by members. Senate cannot enforce committee rules on the floor later. Committees may have traditions affecting procedures, such as restrictions on second-degree amendments during markups. An overview of Senate rules related to committees is provided, followed by tables summarizing each committee's rules on various aspects like meeting day, hearing requirements, quorum, and investigations. Selected unique provisions in committee rules are also highlighted in Table 4. Committee rules are essential for governing actions in committee proceedings and are enforced by members. The Senate's standing rules provide specific requirements that each committee must follow, with some latitude for committees to set their own rules. Each committee must adopt rules, which must generally be published in the Congressional Record by March 1 of the first year of each Congress. This summary provides a background for understanding each committee's individual rules governing key activities. Committees and subcommittees must follow specific rules outlined in the Congressional Record by March 1 of each Congress. Meetings are allowed when the Senate is in session or adjourned, with restrictions on timing. Committees must designate a regular meeting day and announce hearings at least one week in advance, with exceptions for "good cause." Special meetings can be requested by three committee members. Special meetings can be requested by three committee members, and the chair must schedule the meeting within seven days. Committee and subcommittee meetings are generally open to the public, with exceptions for national security reasons. Meetings must be announced in advance and can be broadcasted at the committee's discretion. Committees and subcommittees may set rules for media broadcasting. A majority of members must be present to vote on reporting measures. Proxies cannot be used for quorum. Recordings of open hearings must be made public within 21 days. Committees can allow proxy voting with certain conditions. Proxies cannot affect the outcome of a vote to report a measure. Committees have the power to investigate and issue subpoenas. Minority members can select witnesses for hearings. The minority can select witnesses for hearings, and committees may report bills and resolutions. A majority of the committee must be present to report a measure favorably, and written reports are not always required. Table 1 summarizes each committee's rules on meeting days, notice requirements, and witness selection provisions, including the "good cause" authority for earlier hearings. Senate Rule XXVI, paragraph 4(d) allows the minority to select witnesses for hearings. Rule XXVI, paragraph 4(d) allows the minority to call additional witnesses in certain circumstances, with some committees having their own rules on this. Table 2 focuses on committee rules regarding hearing and business quorums, and requirements for filing amendments before a markup. Some committees require a minority party member to be present for conducting business at meetings. Senate Rule XXVI, paragraph 7(a) requires a majority of the committee to be physically present to report out a measure, known as a "reporting quorum." Committees can set lower quorum requirements, but not less than a third of membership for other business. Some committees restate this rule in their own rules, and some require Senators to file first-degree amendments with the committee. Committees must adhere to Senate Rule XXVI, paragraph 7(a), which mandates a majority presence to report a measure. Some committees may set lower quorum requirements, but not below one-third of the membership for other business. Senators are required to file first-degree amendments with the committee before a markup session, allowing for negotiation and examination of potential issues. Proxy voting is not permitted for committee votes, as physical presence is necessary for reporting a measure. Committees must adhere to Senate Rule XXVI, paragraph 7(a), which mandates a majority presence to report a measure. Proxy voting is not permitted for committee votes, as physical presence is necessary for reporting a measure. Some committees may still allow proxy votes on a motion to report, but such votes cannot count towards the presence of a "reporting quorum" or make a difference in successfully reporting a measure. "Polling" is a method of assessing the committee's position on a matter without physically coming together, but it cannot be used to report out measures or matters. Senate committees are required to have a physical majority present to report a measure or matter, as proxy voting is not allowed for reporting. Polling can be used for internal housekeeping matters, but not for reporting. Some committees have specific rules for action on nominations, including timetables and information requirements. Testifying under oath for nominees varies by committee. Some Senate committees do not have specific rules for investigations or issuing subpoenas, but this does not prevent them from conducting investigations or issuing subpoenas.
